para: If a µ is being built from an ℑ which has a one-to-one correspondence between pixel color and &material;, then the most convenient way to assign &materials; to pixels is to automatically create a &pixelgroup; for each color, and then to assign &materials; to the pixels in each pixel group. The AutoGroup command performs the first part of this process, creating pixel groups for each color of pixel in the given ℑ.

The name_template parameter specifies how the names for the automatically created groups will be generated. It should be a string containing either %c or %n or both. When naming a group, %c will be replaced by the color of the pixels in the group, and %n will be replaced by an integer. Note that %c often leads to unwieldy names, such as RGBColor(red=0.97254901960784312,green=0.9882352941176471,blue=0.0). It may be advisable to manually rename the groups.

caution.para: Images produced by drawing programs that use antialiasing to smooth lines are generally not suitable candidates for AutoGroup. Even if an antialiased image appears to contain only a few colors, it will generally have many slightly different colors at the borders between regions, and AutoGrouping will create a large number of groups. On antialiased images it's best to select pixels with, for example, and assign them to a group manually with .
